head.title: G.M. Doubles Its Stake in Suzuki Motor to 20%

hedline.hl1: G.M. Doubles Its Stake in Suzuki Motor to 20%

abstract.p: General Motors Corp doubles its stake in Suzuki Motor Corp to 20 percent and GM's chairman John F Snmith Jr joins Suzuki's board; photo (M)

block.p: The General Motors Corporation doubled its stake in the Suzuki Motor Corporation to 20 percent today and G.M.'s top executive joined Suzuki's board.

The deal, announced by the two automakers in Tokyo, expanded a close relationship between them that goes back almost 20 years, when Suzuki first began supplying small cars to G.M., the world's largest automotive company.
The General Motors Corporation doubled its stake in the Suzuki Motor Corporation to 20 percent today and G.M.'s top executive joined Suzuki's board.

The deal, announced by the two automakers in Tokyo, expanded a close relationship between them that goes back almost 20 years, when Suzuki first began supplying small cars to G.M., the world's largest automotive company.
G.M. is hoping that Suzuki will help increase its share of the market in Asia, where the automotive industry is expected to grow the fastest in the next several years.

''We wanted to build on that history of relationship with General Motors,'' said Osamu Suzuki, chairman and chief executive of Suzuki, who appeared at a news conference with his G.M. counterpart, John F. Smith Jr.

In agreeing to name Mr. Smith as a nonexecutive director of Suzuki, Mr. Suzuki said: ''We wanted someone who could advise us on areas of strategic importance. We are grateful to get an excellent person.''

The Suzuki-G.M. deal is the latest in a series of transactions by foreign automakers to gain a greater presence in Japan. DaimlerChrysler A.G. has arranged to take a 34 percent ownership stake in Mitsubishi Motors.
The Ford Motor Company has control of the Mazda Motor Corporation, and Renault of France holds a 37 percent interest in the Nissan Motor Company.

G.M. also holds stakes in Isuzu Motors Ltd. and Subaru, a unit of Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. But the G.M.-Suzuki alliance is characterized by unusually close personal relations between the two chairmen, who have known each other since G.M. and Suzuki first entered into an alliance in 1981.
Takaki Nakanishi, an automotive analyst with Merrill Lynch in Tokyo, said the choice of Mr. Smith as a board member ''showed G.M. had no intention to control'' Suzuki management.

Suzuki also differs from several of its larger Japanese competitors in that it is financially strong, unencumbered by heavy debts or sluggish sales. Digging deep into the small- car niche, it has carved a firm presence in Japan and overseas markets and has not lost money since 1949.
Mr. Suzuki and Mr. Smith said they considered the relationship a strategic partnership and that Suzuki would remain independent.

Analysts said a small-car manufacturer like Suzuki was now more important to G.M. than ever in its strategy to build a greater presence in Asian markets, especially after the company lost in a bidding war with Ford over the acquisition of Daewoo Motors of South Korea.
''Our future depends on the success in Asia,'' said Rudolph Schlais, president of G.M.'s Asia-Pacific operations, who attended the news conference.

In an important step toward working cooperatively to expand in Asia, Suzuki will start manufacturing YGM-1, a jointly developed minicar between G.M. and Suzuki, in a plant in Kosai, a city near Mount Fuji west of Tokyo, in September 2001.
Mr. Suzuki, 70, has been chief executive of Suzuki Motor since 1978.

Asked which side first proposed raising the G.M. stake to 20 percent, Mr. Suzuki responded, ''That was done by 'a un no kokyu' with Mr. Smith,'' using a Japanese expression that roughly translates into they ''knew each other's thoughts without using any words.''
